comment._content: I haven't found anything out about the delightful Miss W, but on Feb 7th 1920, 2 weeks before this photo, her brother (I assume) Lieutenant John Parnell Mandeville, Royal Navy, of Anner Castle, ... grandson of Lord Vesey, second Lord Congleton, eldest son of the late Henry Ambrose and the Hon Sarah Cecilia, announced his engagement to Florence Ethylle, only daughter of Lieutenant-Colonel and Mrs L G Page of Kingstown , Co Dublin. They married on 16th June that year.

I did find names for her parents, and more information on Miss W. Mandeville's siblings...

Henry Ambrose Mandeville and the Hon. Sarah Cecilia Parnell (born 5 August 1868) married on 21 November 1895.

John Parnell Mandeville, born 15 September 1896
Geoffrey Fortescue Mandeville, born 15 May 1901
Maurice Valentine Mandeville, born 7 November 1903
Catharine Cecilia Mandeville, born 3 June 1899

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Bingo! According to the 1911 census, these Mandevilles were living at 32, The Common, Woolwich: Henry (aged 69) Head, b Curraghmore, Co Waterford Cecilia (42) Wife, b Streatham Hill Glady (?Gladys)(25) daughter, born Sidcup, Kent Winifred(21) daughter, born Woolwich, Kent (profession -independent means) Cattierine (?Catherine) (11) daughter, born Middlesex Geoffrey (9) son, born Clonmel Maurice (7) son, born Clonmel Desmond (4 months) son, born Woolwich Elise (17) niece, born (?) Clondalkin, co Dublin and three servants 1911 Census return 32 The Common Woolwich It also says that Cecilia has 5 children, so presumably Glady and Winifred were Henry's daughters from a previous marriage, which would make Florence Ethylle her half-sister-in-law. Presumably John was away at school by this time. Why Woolwich and not Anner Castle? In the account (in the Times, London) of Anner Castle being burnt down in 1926, it says "The castle ... had not been used by the family for some years, except for holidays spent there ..." although Geoffrey's 1943 obituary describes him as the son of the late Henry Ambrose Mandeville RN and Hon Mrs Manderville of Anner Castle.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Here's the promised article from the Irish Times of Thursday, 14 October 1926 on the Anner Castle Fire. A quite bizarre, and not a little Gothic, account and it mentions that Miss Mandeville (Winifred? Still unmarried in 1926?) owned the Castle: "Little further light was thrown on the burning of Anner Castle, Country Tipperary, and the death of the caretaker, a man named Burke, at the inquest which was held yesterday in the harness room of the Castle Yard by Dr. Patrick Stokes, Deputy Coroner. The mansion was gutted, save for one wing, and the caretaker was found in the coach-house with the top of his head blown off, and a fowling piece lying across his body. Burke lived alone in the yard lodge near the Castle, which was uninhabited. The evidence showed that he was an eccentric man, but a careful and devoted servant. He was very suspicious, and when the staff of servants were at the Castle during the residence of the family, he fancied that attempts were made to put powder in his plate, and used to change places with the others at the table. During his seven years at the Castle it was said that he never went to Mass, but upon his body were found some religious books. There was also a deposit receipt for £43, lodged in the bank on October 1st, and apparently he had hoarded his wages, and then decided to put them away. Mr. O'Brien, solicitor for Miss Mandeville, who owned the Castle, said that the affair was a mystery, and would remain a mystery, but he submitted that it was quite evident that Burke's mind had become unhinged and that he took his life. Mr. Reilly, solicitor for the next-of-kin, asked the jury to return an open verdict. He contended that there was no direct evidence to show how the wound was inflicted. The jury found that death was due to shock, caused by a gunshot wound, self-inflicted, during temporary insanity. Superintendent Fitzgerald said that there had been a suspicion that a horse, which was found dead in the stable, had been poisoned, but Mr. Mulcahy, V.S, who examined the animal, said that it died of natural causes, and that there was no sign of poisoning. It was rather strange that the horse was found dead in the stable at the same time that the deceased man's body was found. The animal was seen in a field on the previous evening all right."
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Thanks for that. Meanwhile, the plot thickens: The Times(London) Jan 23rd 1963, deaths column: MANDEVILLE, On 21st Jan 1963, at Suir Lodge, Clonmel, GLADYS ELIZABETH, second daughter of HENRY AMBROSE MANDEVILLE of Anner Castle, Clonmel, a dearly beloved sister. So Gladys didn't marry and might be the 'Miss Manderville' in the newspaper report, but why does it describe her as second daughter, when in the 1911 census she is the eldest? Perhaps there is yet another sibling, who died before 1911? And the list of guests at Geoffrey Fortescue Mandeville's wedding in August 1933 lists only one Miss Manderville (apart from a Miss Ida Mandeville who was a bridesmaid). Assuming that's Gladys, then Winifred is no longer Miss in 1933. Or, perish the thought, dead. Or she'd fallen out with Geoffrey and wasn't invited.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: This is the report in the London Times on April 8th 1927 BURNING OF AN IRISH CASTLE CLAIM FOR COMPENSATION A claim for £32,000 compendsation for the destruction of Anner Castle, the residence of the Manderville family, on the banks of the Anner, near Clonmel, Came before the Clonmel Circuit CIrcuit Court yesterday. The claimants were Lieutenant Mandeville, Mr John P Mandeville, and the Provincial Bank. The castle, rebuilt 60 years ago at a cost of £50,000, had not been used by the family for some years, except for hoidays spent there last August and September. One morning in Octoberthe castle was found to be burnuing in several places. A horse was discovered poisoned in a stable, and in a storehouse Burke, the caretaker of the castle, who lived there alone, was found dead lying on a rug, his brains blown out and a gun lying across his breast. Counsel for the claimants said it appeared that Burkeburned the castle, poinoned the horse, and blew his brains out, though no-one saw him do these deeds The defence was that the burning was the ac of a deranged man not responsible for his acts. The JUDGE held that Burke was criminally resposible for the destruction. The question of compensation was reserved to next session. So was the horse poisoned or not?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: This evenings installment: According to the British birth-marriage-death (BMD) register, Henry Ambrose Mandeville married Maud Augusta St G Heyman in the 2nd quater of 1881 Winifred Mary Mandeville was born in Woolwich in the 2nd quarter of 1889 - therefore 7 to 10 months before her mother died. According to the Irish BMD index WInifred Mary Mandeville married in the 3rd quarter of 1920 at Clonmel - just a few months after this picture was taken. No wonder she looks happy. I can't help thinking that A H Poole was hired to do the wedding photos and they are somewhere in the NLI collections.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I can't see why the link isn't working. It's not a subscription service, but doesn't tell you much anyway so I've removed it. I've just searched for marriage notices in the Times (London) for Mandevilles between July and September 1920, and I didn't find Winifred, but I did find Evangeline Maud, eldest daughter of Henry A Manderville of Anner Castle. So that's the missing sibling whose existence was hinted at in Gladys's death notice. She married in Columbo on 19th August. A search for Owens during the same period turned up trumps. Winifred married Henry Barton Owens (b 1889) on 6th July 1920

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I was idly looking through a 1921 copy of the British Medical Journal, as you do, and I came across the obituary of Henry Barton Owens , Winifred's husband. Having survived the WW1 trenches as a medic, he died of septicemia on January 15th 1921, just over 6 months after marrying WInifred. So the WInifred in the picture, no doubt looking forward to a long and happy life as the wife of a country doctor, was a widow less than a year later. What became of her after that? I've found 2 instances of 'Mrs Owens' as a guest at weddings in the 1930s. One in 1931 at the wedding of Major E O Springfield and Miss Elnith Irene Watson in London, and I think this is 'our' WInifred, because the next name on the list is 'Mr Mandeville' , and because Miss Watson's parents lived at Ballingane, Clonmel, so I assume they would have known the Mandevilles. The second is at her brother Geoffrey's wedding in 1933. So in summary 1889 Winifred Mary Mandeville born at Woolwich, the third of 3 sisters 1890 Her mother dies 1895 Her father marries again and they go on to have another 5 children 1920 She is photographed in a magnificent hat by A H Poole 1920 She marries a doctor, Henry Barton Owens and he starts practising in Northamptonshire 1921 Her husband Henry dies after 6 months of marriage 1933 She is still alive and hasn't remarried

Thank you very much for all of your hard work on this lovely photo. I've added your Winifred summary in the description above.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: No - thank you. I'd better stop stalking her now.

comment.author: 75837247@N08
comment._content: Just to say that I am the son of John Parnell Mandeville, and Winifred Mary Owens was my aunt.  Henry Barton Owens kept a diary throughout WW1 in which he put watercolours of the scenes that he saw - my uncle Desmond Mandeville placed this in the Imperial War Museum and this can be seen there if asked for.    Some have said that the burning of Anner Castle provided a background for Rebecca (Daphne de Maurier) but this is probably fanciful.   There is a view of the castle in the Clonmel library archives dating from 1854 approximately - and the castle has been available for renting for holidays for a number of years.   This photograph shows Winifred at her happiest - she retained a glorious sense of humour till she died but there was always a certain sadness - not surprising really.   Dr Henry Owens chest never recovered from the poison gas he inhaled when tending gassed soldiers.  Winifred met him when he was in convalescence near her cousin (Springfield) in Norfolk.    Bob Mandeville

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/75837247@N08] Thank you so much for getting in touch! As you can see above, everyone loves this photo of your aunt, and it is lovely to know that she had, as you say "a glorious sense of humour". Great Mandeville family history detective work has been done here, but it was very saddening to learn that Dr Owens died so soon after their marriage. Your information about the poison gas explains a lot...

Thanks again.
Carol Maddock
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 83407051@N04
comment._content: Interesting  stuff from everyone re the Mandevilles. We knew the Rev. Maurice who lived in Clonmel for very many years as my husband  is the resident organist in Old St. Mary's Church here in Clonmel. . My  mother's cousins were Mandevilles and were, Katie, Elizabeth and Josie and were upholsterers and lived in William St. in Clonmel - all reamined single.I think they had a brother but know nothing of him. The story was that their father married a Catholic girl, an uphosterer and brought up the girls as Catholics! The 3 of them joined Cumann na Mban  and there is a photo surviving of them from around this time. The Reverend Maurice knew about  this incident in their family and he also told us that his family was related to the Patriot Mandeville from Mitchelstown!  So even though we were born on the wrong side of the blanket I suppose we are half relations of the beautiful Winifred in the Photo!  Maureen

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Here we go On the 27th April, the day after Sarah Cecilia's death, this notice appeared in the Hants and Berks Gazette. No report of the death - presumably it occurred too late for the paper's deadline. One week later (4th May) is the report of the inquest, which was held the day after the death.
Inquest part 1 (which also shows that Henry continued to preach at Victoria Hall) Inquest part 2 The evidence of Mr Mandeville and of Mrs Daniell. The 1911 census shows the Daniells' address as Sandhill, on London Road, near to Bear Barn Farm, where Dr Maturin "found the lady dead" Inquest part 3 The evidence of Col Davey, the driver of the car Inquest part 4 The evidence of Dr Maturin, Richard Dowsett, and William Cripps. Also the jury's verdict.
In summary, what appears to have happened was this:
Mrs M appears to have been unsteady on her feet and/or lost in thought Col Davey in his car came up behind her and slowed down. Mrs M walks into the road, and then takes a step back to the side Col Davey thinks she has seen him, and accelerates to go past Mrs M continues to cross the road and is hit by Col Davey's car ("at about 9 mph").
On the 11th May is a report of the funeral . No doubt our Winifred was there. On the 18th May, this notice appeared. I can't help thinking that the sentiments ("time is short, eternity near; death is busy") were inspired by his recent loss. I rode back from Basingstoke Library via Hartley Wintney, and had a quick look at Victoria Hall - as village halls go it is rather grand. My route home then took me past Taplin's Farm, where the Mandevilles were staying during their Mission at Hartley Wintney.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] 2 of the 3 librarians I spoke to were Irish. NLI spies, no doubt. 

When I asked to see the papers for April/May 1912, someone already had the 1912 microfilm and out and was looking at the April 20th edition of the paper. Spooky!

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Lieut H S Davey was promoted to Captain in September 1894 (18th Hussars) In the 1890s he was in India, where he married and where his eldest son, Horace Balfour Davey, was born. Capt Hon H S Davey was listed as one of the injured officers on the Octavia which sailed from Cape town in March 1900 In 1901 he arranged a dinner for officers of the garrison of Ladysmith - the dinner was to be held on 28th Febuary, the anniversary of the relief. In October 1902 Major Davey rejoined his regiment. His father, Lord Davey (also Horace), a lawyer and politician, died in 1907. 1923 - he's still attending Ladysmith dinners. Lt. Col The Hon Horace Scott Davey CMG died in May 1935.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I don't think Col Davey could have been driving to his son's wedding. His eldest son would have been 18 at the time, and didn't marry, and his second son married in 1925. The only passenger mentioned at the inquest was his chauffeur, Dowsett (although his wife may have been in the car and just not mentioned).

comment.author: 58391555@N07
comment._content: What a wonderful photo and thread about Winifred Mandeville and her family. I was at Greenwich Heritage Centre (actually in Woolwich) yesterday and found these two pictures of Woolwich Common. I am pretty sure that one of the tall white houses is number 32, the Mandevilles' house. One of the archivists helped me to locate it with a local directory and some maps. Apologies for the quality; my scanner is fairly basic and the C19 photo is scanned from quite an old looking photocopy! C19: www.flickr.com/photos/phines_pics/8668869487/in/photostream Mid C20 www.flickr.com/photos/phines_pics/8669906284/in/photostream/ I'm not good on cars so I can't really tell when the photograph was taken. Sadly this elegant terrace was torn down and redeveloped in the early 70s.

comment.author: 58391555@N07
comment._content: I took these photographs this afternoon at the same location on Woolwich Common. Redevelopment hasn't improved it: www.flickr.com/photos/phines_pics/8669198085/in/photostream www.flickr.com/photos/phines_pics/8670281670/in/photostream/

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/phines_pics] Oh dear! Much prefer the "old" houses. 

Thanks so much for taking the trouble!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 58391555@N07
comment._content: No trouble at all, just the sort of job I love, although it would have been nice to find the original house still there.  Your thread gave me a bit of background on someone I've been curious about since the 80s, when I had a temp job several hundred miles from here churning out letters for a large and dull organisation.  The only entertainment I could find was in the names of the people my boss was writing to.  Most of the names I enjoyed were vaguely smutty or plain unfortunate, but the Reverend Maurice Valentine Mandeville was entrancing and unforgettable.  I never met him or even spoke to him, but have often wondered about him and the other day, prompted by a possible forth-coming visit to Tipperary, I googled him.  You can imagine how surprised I was on reading this thread, to discover that his childhood home was just a couple of miles from where I live now!

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/phines_pics] I came across that 14 months ago, and came to the conclusion it probably wasn't the same person, although I'm not sure why. Possibly because she was Winifred Owens by then, although of course she might have used her maiden name.

There are copies in the National Library of Scotland and the British Library in Yorkshire. And nowhere else, it seems.

comment._content: Yes, that's why I said "possibly"...... I actually had a look on Free BMD and there was one other Winifred Mandeville born in the UK who would have been the right sort of age.  Possibly others in Ireland too - but I can't think there were too many!
